titleStmt.title: Somnus, Why Art Thou Still to Me Unkind?
Poem #120

encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be futher explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or miniscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

app.rdg: PG#[Untitled]
Somnus, Why Art Thou Still to Me Unkind?
AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

This fragment of a poem, in what is probably Pulter’s hand, appears on a loose sheet in a folder associated with the bound volume in which her other poems are found. Although a complete copy might someday be found, Pulter appears not to have finished this experimental dream vision about a relatively recent event: the 1667 battle, known as the Raid on the Medway, which ended in the destruction by the Dutch navy of the fort and shipyard at Sheerness, on England’s east coast. Part of the Second Anglo-Dutch War, this was one of the worst defeats ever suffered by the British navy, which saw many warships destroyed or captured and the hasty arrangement by Charles II of an unfavorable treaty. The few extant verses of what promises an epic treatment of these events are framed by the speaker’s recurrent nightmare visions which mingle her distress with an incongruous perception of Sheerness remaining “unconquered” despite the “purple gore” that sprinkles the sea. The speaker’s horrified amazement joins that of the powerful and resplendent water gods and goddesses, mustering (too late, it must be said) as British reinforcements under Saturn’s command. Neptune, Triton, Nereus, Doris: the speaker, perched on a rock above the fray, witnesses a catalogue of mythic powerhouses whom she has imaginatively installed into current political events. What dreamy counterfactual scenario might have ensued, if the poem continued past its opening catalogue and into the martial action one might expect to follow? We will only know if the poem’s continuation one day comes to light.

app.rdg: ſomnuson loose sheet, in folder associated with manuscript; hand appears same as in “The Weepeinge Wishe” why art thou ſtill to mee unkinde?
SomnusRoman god of sleep, why art thou still to me unkind?
Why doe all els ſuch comfort finde
Why do all else such comfort find
In thy imbrace? but I and only I
In thy embrace? But I, and only I,
Allternately (aye mee) doe live and die

Alternately (ay me) do live and diewake and sleep; sleep was commonly referred to as the image of death; for instance, John Donne calls rest and sleep Death’s “pictures” (“Death Be Not Proud,” l. 5)..
Thy fellow Morphius too doth ſhew his ſpite
Thy fellow Morpheusson of Somnus and Roman god of dreams too doth show his spite
When from his Horney gate [?]single letter, possibly “d,” blotted on bottom half hee doth affright

When from his horny gateThe gates of horn and ivory is a literary image (originally from The Odyssey) distinguishing two kinds of dreams: those passing through the gate of horn are true, while those passing through the gate of ivory are deceptive. Many writers used the term “horny gate” to describe Morpheus’s dream invasions. See, for instance, Du Bartas His Divine Weeks and Works, trans. Josuah Sylvester (London, 1641), p. 249. he doth affright
My troubled ſoul, as hee did t’hother night
My troubled soul, as he did th’other night.
Oh yblotted only on top half my ſad hart would itt might prove a dream
O my sad heart, would it might prove a dream!
In that uncounquerd sheere wher Thameses ſtreame

In that unconquered Sheer, when Thames’s streamAt Sheerness (on England’s eastern coast) the river Medway (mentioned in the next line) joins with the estuary of the Thames river; it is presumably called “unconquered” here in relation to the 1667 Dutch attack there in the Second Anglo-Dutch War, despite the fact that both contemporary and later accounts consider the battle there to have been a resounding defeat of the English navy.
Joyened with faire Medwaye did,dothdirectly over “did” their tribute paye
Joined with fair Medway doth their tributean offering paid as a duty, here also alluding to the the fact that a “tributary” is a stream flowing into a river pay,
Thar on a lofty rock mee thought I laye
There on a lofty rock me thought I lay;
Then on the tremblinge booſomesecond “o” blotted on right half of the deepe
Then, on the trembling bosom of the deep,
Huge floods of tears poore Thames did weepe
Huge floods of tears poor Thames did weep
To“+” in left margin ſee the ſea ſprinc’led with purple gore
ToA mark (“+”) appears in the left margin, as though to signal an insertion of a phrase which is not present in the manuscript. see the sea sprinkled with purple gore.
The ſad Nereades did much deplore
The sad Nereidesin Greek legend, the fifty daughters of Doris and Nereus; sea nymphs did much deplorelament
This change, omendirectly over “change” great Neptune was amazed
This omen. Great NeptuneRoman god of water and the sea was amazed
As hee upon those blooddy billowblot immediately after may obscure final “s” gaz’d
As he upon those bloody billows gazed;
Then instantly hee bad blu“bad” may have read “bid” originally, or reverse; “blu” appears written over “buw” Triton ſound
Then, instantly he bid blue Tritonson of Neptune, represented as a fish with a human head, who makes the ocean roar by blowing through his shell sound
His wrethed Trumpe t’was hard the Oceane rownd
His wreathéd trumptrumpet—’twas heard the ocean round—
To ſummun each greatſea \“ſea \” written directly atop “great” God, and Godes faire
To summon each sea god and goddess fair,
That to“t” appears to correct earlier “o” our narrough ſeas they should repaire
That to our narrow seas they should repairreturn.
Then did they come from every ſea and strand
Then did they come from every sea and strandshore, coast
To heer their kinge ſaturnius dread command
To hear their king Saturnus’sLatin for Saturn, the Roman god associated by the Romans with the Greek god Kronos, the father of the first-generation Olympians dread command.
ſome did bestride Philanthropes broad backe

Some did bestride Philanthrope’sThe name (etymologically, “lover of humanity”) refers in classical literature to the dolphin; it is based on the animal’s alleged friendliness to people, which in some cases included allowing people to ride (“bestride”) them. broad back;
The Nimphesfinal part of “h” appears added to earlier “l,” crowded between surrounding letters in Perley ſhells, not one thar“a” appears to correct earlier “ei” lacks
The nymphssemi-divine spirits in the form of maidens inhabiting the sea, rivers, mountains, woods, trees; often portrayed in poetry as attendants on a god in pearly shells, not one there lacks
Of all great Oceanus watry traine

Of all great Oceanus’sin Greek mythology, the son of Uranus (Heaven) and Gaia (Earth); the personification of the great river believed to encircle the world wat’ry traina body of attendants or followers,
But floteinge came upon the frothey maine
But floating came upon the frothy mainopen sea.
Emperiall Nereus frist did lead the waye
Imperial Nereusan old sea god, father of the Nereides first did lead the way,
Who o’ur the tumed waves bares cheeffest ſwaye
Who o’er the tumidswelling; puffed with wind waves bears chiefest sway;
Rich purpletwice struck-through orient gemms his purple robe adorninge

Rich orient gemspossibly, pearls, especially those from near India; alternatively, any jewel from or associated with the Orient, the part of the globe east of Europe; “orient” could refer to a bright red color (like sunrise in the east), to the color or lustre of the best pearls (understood to come from the East), or to anything brilliant or resplendent. his purple robe adorning,
Which cast a luster like the blusheinge morninge
Which cast a luster like the blushing morning.
This glistringe Charott drawn with Cro pranceinge fishe
This glist’ringfor “glistering,” meaning sparkling or glittering chariot drawn with prancing fish,
Which would have ſatisfied prowed [?]diagonally struck-through text, possibly “ff[?]” Phaetons wishe

Which would have satisfied proud Phaeton’sPhaeton was the rash son of Helios, the Greek sun god, who, when riding his father’s chariot, lost control of it and almost destroyed the world by fire (had Zeus not killed Phaeton and restored order). wish.
Just by his ſide faire fruetfull Doris came
Just by his side, fair fruitful Dorisa sea goddess, wife of Nereus and mother of the Nereides came,
Whos numeros iſsew doth inlarge her fame
Whose numerous issueoffspring doth enlarge her fame;
Riche Orient Perls her ſnowey neck did grace
Rich orient pearls her snowy neck did grace;
Her ſparklinge Crowne gave luster to her face
Her sparkling crown gave luster to her face;
Between her brests a rich Carbuncle ſhone
Between her breasts a rich carbunclea large precious stone of a red or fiery color; a mythical jewel reputed to emit light in darkness shone;
The univerce afforded not a ſtone
The universe afforded not a stone
That equal’d itt for ſplendentie of light
That equalled it for splendencysplendor, brilliance of light.
Itt rul’d the rest as Cinthia doth the night
It ruled the rest as Cynthiathe personification of the moon doth the nightThe poem breaks off here and is unfinished.
